review_text: We had a great time staying at the Pink Pine with our friends! Two of our other friends rented the Pine Cottage, which is behind this rental, on the same property, and they loved their stay as well! The Pine Cottage is privately secluded from the main house, and we definitely would have still felt we had a private space, even if we hadn’t known the other renters. Everyone in our party loved the comfortable king beds. We wish all places would put king beds in every room! The kitchen is well stocked, and we did a lot of cooking in it and had everything we needed. The property was spotless inside and out, and the fire pit and gas grill on the patio were perfect. There is plenty of parking, and the neighborhood seems very safe and quiet, despite being so close to SFA. We had one small problem during our trip, but our wonderful host, Jennifer, got it taken care of right away. She responded quickly to everything and was great to work with. We can’t wait to stay again on our next trip!

I cannot begin to thank Jennifer enough. This weekend was difficult for my family. We were visiting Nacogdoches for my Aunt's funeral. Jennifer was very accommodating and understood our needs.
The Pink Pine was absolutely adorable. You are greeted by the pink door as you pull into the driveway. The covered parking gives you ample coverage should there be inclement weather. inside the beautiful decor was so inviting.
The kitchen was wonderful with bottled water available and a coffee bar with a wide selection of teas and coffees.
Now let’s talk about the bedrooms and bathrooms. All rooms were beautifully decorated with wonderful mattresses and bed linens. The bathrooms had fluffy/plush towels and plenty of them. There were even soft make up towels provided.
We didn’t have time to venture outside to enjoy the fire pit, and the grill. Next time we visit Nacogdoches we will certainly book The Punk Pine and sit around the pit.
Thank you Jennifer for going above and beyond.

review_text: An easy walk to almost everything in historic downtown. With a secure coded door lock, and seamless check-in, this frame upstairs-garage-apartment is a quaint little abode that has everything you need for a stay in ‘Nac. Comfortable bed, closet, AC units in bedroom/LR, small but full kitchen (range, fancy coffee-stuff-we-don’t-know-about, a large Keurig, glassware, microwave, fridge, comfy living room furniture, and a smart TV) Make no mistake: the premises is rustic and authentic. The cabinets and bathtub are probably original to the structure and haven’t been HGTV’d to a bright shiny finish. The stairs are old and steep, there is paneling and leather furniture that is comfortably loved, but we think that’s part of the Airbnb kitsch and charm. We drank our coffee on the elevated deck at an iron patio set overlooking the historic old cemetery and walked to the city-center wineries and antique shops. If you require brand-new, flawless, shiny hotel style accommodations- maybe this is not your jam; but if comfy boho is appealing to you, you’ll enjoy this little gem close to everything in ‘Nac.

review_text: This is a huge space for the price--three bedrooms, large living room & dining area, full kitchen, laundry machines, and a small back patio with table & chairs, grill, and outdoor lighting. It was well-equipped with linens, soap, dishes, silverware, pots & pans, glassware, coffee, and some cooking basics. Everything was spotlessly clean and in working order. There was good wifi, cable television, & Netflix available, as well as games and books. There's even a crib in the master bedroom closet, if needed. The house is tastefully decorated and well-arranged for families or multiple occupants. It's walking distance to the small downtown area of Nacogdoches, which has restaurants and shops to enjoy, and a quick five minute drive to the SFA university campus. The neighborhood is an older historic neighborhood, and there's currently some construction along the street in front, including some large metal plates in the road that bang when cars go by--but this is likely temporary. Overall, it was a great place to stay and one that I'd gladly use again on future visits.

First. The chair. It looks harmless enough. It’s not. The chair is unusually lightweight. It is built of sticks and upholstered, but the stuffing is minimal. The sticks, glued together to give this thing it’s chair-like appearance, are sharp and placed exactly where you will likely expect soft stuffing. You won’t find it. I often have a hard time getting out of a chair. Not this one. I found myself plenty motivated to get out of this one. Getting into this thing is the hard part. You must sneak up on it.
